course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Behavioral Games
course.description: This course explores strategic behavior in interpersonal settings as approximated by games such as the prisoner's dilemma game, the dictator game, the trust game, the public goods game, etc. While we will derive equilibrium behavior using game theory, the course will focus on the systematic deviations in reality from equilibrium behavior, the various explanations for these deviations, and the design of games to study individual traits and social preferences.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: NOT a CC
reviews.comment_content:
Before Mid-Term:
Prisoner's Dilemma, Lottery Games, Utility Functions etc.

After Mid-Term:
High school economics, with some calculus in handling Demand & Supply & Profit-Maximization; Excludability; Market Failure etc.

Things that could be simple were deliberately complicated & caused much difficulties for me even as a student who had taken DSE Econ in the past. Topics were quite a mess & had lots of ambiguity, lowering much of my motivation to conduct extra reading.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has a native English accent, probably because she had studied in the US for 10+ years before she came to UST.  

Her native English accent has only served as a “golden coat” for her “teaching”, nothing more.

I don't want to be mean & so this metaphor may be good enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-Term: 30%
Final Exam: 30%
6-man Project: 30% (design a game for classmates to play in the last two weeks of semester)
Attendance: 10% (counted by in-class submission of answers to practice questions)

Exams have both MC, SQ & LQ. LQ involve tedious arithmetic calculations (which I think Gaussian Eliminations are even less tedious than the arithmetic LQ of this course's exams).

I got B－.

She claimed that she followed the grading distribution suggested by the university, which is:

A: 15%
B: 40%
C: ...
reviews.comment_workload:
Barely standard. This is NOT a CC. I would NOT recommend you taking this if you want to fulfill CC requirements more.

Even a classmate who is of ACCT major claimed that this course was desperately hard.

reviews.author: tycin
reviews.comment_content: It contains a lot of maths and some simple economic. Experiments will be carried in class once a week.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She will only read to material on power point and write some math equation on write to copy.
She is willing to answer questions on class, and
reviews.comment_grading:
The final exam of this class is not in the period for the final exam, it will be at the last teaching lesson. Revising earlier in needed.

Also, although the class does not require attendance, you needed to finish the in-class exercise for 10% of marks. (the answer is provided to copied during class)
reviews.comment_workload:
Low
the project is simple, it required a group of 6 people to slightly modified an experiment that has played in class before to test your own hypothesis.

reviews.author: Reese
reviews.comment_content: Game Theories are interesting but a bit easy. Not challenging enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is kind but she's not really good at leading the lesson's process.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two tests and one group project to measure the grade.
Marks in grades diverges a lot according to understanding for the theories by students. I wonder why they can get low marks even if the questions are so direct and clear...
reviews.comment_workload: Very low workload. My suggestion is to attend all lessons because it's fun to participate in the games,  and it's easier to understand the concepts.

reviews.author: yooy
reviews.title: Easy to get good grades if you have paid attention
reviews.comment_content:
There is nothing about psychological in the lessons. Most of them are about economics, so you will feel familiar with those concepts if you have studied economics in high school or uni.
The first chapter is about demand and supply curve, which is exactly the same as high school curricular, but sadly she didn't put that into midterm:(
There are also many in class activities, most of them are interesting coz they make the lessons less boring.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She just read out the PowerPoints so lessons are boring. However, she does show all the steps of in class exercises clearly, so you just have to jot them down and study them, because they are included in the exams. The exam questions (long questions) are exactly the same as the in class exercise, so you don't have to worry about the calculation or plotting graphs. I strongly suggest you to pay attention when she is explaining the in class exercises, but other than that, you can just take a nap or watch youtube because you can still understand the lectures by going through the ppt for around 15mins after lessons lol.
The prof is also very nice, she answered all of my questions clearly and patiently, so don't be afraid to ask. I found some of the concepts hard to understand as I weren't paying attention in class lol.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair enough, the final exam and project results are not provided. I got 2 marks below mean in midterm but I still got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Little workload, there is no homework but a group project in a group of 6. I finished the project with 1 of my friend within 2 days, probably 10 hours even though there were free-riders lol.

reviews.author: Keju
reviews.title: Don't be fooled by the course title
reviews.comment_content:
I came here expecting some psychology.. It was all economic games. Game theory.

Even someone in MAEC final year said this course is really hard, especially for a 1000-level one.

Experiment/economic game will be conducted in class every other class (once a week).

Note that you're expected to know basic integration and differentiation (middle school stuff).

Pit Market
Matrix Games
Risk
Random strategies
- - mid term - -
Monopoly and Cournot
Institutions and Market Power
Market Failure
Public goods
Ultimatum and Dictator
Trust
reviews.comment_teaching:
Almost everything is included in the powerpoint presentations posted to canvas, except for some (usually math formulas you'll need) things that she just decides to write on the board and not include in the presentation. She mostly just reads the powerpoint presentation.

The things taught are pretty confusing. The class being totally unresponsive made it super boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% ：In-class exercises and experiment worksheets
30% ：Exam 1
30% ：Exam 2
30% ：Group project

In-class exercises and experiment worksheets are just their way of collecting attendance (full credit as long as you do it). There will be one every class.
The content included in the exams are not cumulative.
Exam 2 will be held during the last class, not during finals period.
For the group project, design an experiment to conduct in class and actually conduct it.
Exam format:
- T/F questions
- MCQ
- Fill in the blanks
- Long questions (math..)



I have full attendance (full credit for in-class exercises and experiment worksheets)
Exam 1: 0.5SD above mean
mean: ~66, SD: 22, out of 110
Exam 2 & project unknown
Tried really hard for exam 2 and project.

Final grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
Only workload is attendance and group project (and also study for the exams but that's not really considered here).

Project workload:
- brainstorm ideas (duh)
- write a proposal, with experiment design and everything
- actually conduct the experiment (powerpoint presentation, response sheets, whatever else you use)
- experiment write-up
